texts.shortText: Although this small species has long been well-known to divers and has an established common name, it has yet to be scientifically described and formally named. The column is marked with rows of violet or purple spots and while normally short and squat, can be greatly extended to allow the animal to bend over and feed on items on the adjacent rock surface. The oral disc is plain and lacks any radiating stripes, but there are usually purple spots at either end of the mouth. There are up to 48 short, stubby white tentacles with purple tips.
Column typically about 10 mm high and wide. When extended can reach at least 50 mm length.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Cape Columbine on West coast to southern KwaZulu-Natal.
Uncommon and usually found singly on vertical rocks below low tide level. Nothing further known about biology.

Prey unknown, but almost all anemones are unselective predators, feeding on a wide variety of invertebrate taxa. This species has been observed to greatly extend the body and reach over to engulf living organisms on adjacent rock, but what species are eaten has not been determined.
No details known, but most anemones can both reproduce sexually by releasing sperm and eggs into the water to merge and form plankton larvae, and by division of the adult.

Possible to confuse with Violet spotted anemone (Anthostella stephensoni), which is also cream and has purple spots on the column, but that species is larger and has distinctive bright red radiating lines across the oral disc from the mouth to the bases of the tentacles.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 26).

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.
